01.text: Jesus begins to describe events that will happen before he comes again during the end times.
It is implied that Jesus was not in the temple itself. He was in the courtyard around the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

01.ref: Do you not see all these things?
01.text: Jesus uses a question to make the disciples think deeply about what he will tell them. AT: "Let me tell you something about all these buildings." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

01.ref: not one stone will be left on another that will not be torn down
01.text: It is implied that enemy soldiers will tear down the stones. This can be stated in active form. AT: "when the enemy soldiers come, they will tear down every stone in these buildings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

03.ref: What will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the age
03.text: Here "your coming" refers to when Jesus will come in power, establishing God's reign on earth and bringing this age to an end. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

03.ref: Be careful that no one leads you astray
03.text: "Be careful that you do not believe anyone who lies to you about these things"

03.ref: many will come in my name
03.text: Here "name" refers to "in the authority" or "as the representative" of someone. AT: "many will claim that they have come as my representative" or "many will say they speak for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

06.ref: See that you are not troubled
06.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let these things trouble you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

06.ref: For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom
06.text: Both of these mean the same thing. Jesus is emphasizing that people everywhere will fight each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This refers to the pains a woman feels before giving birth to a child. This metaphor means these wars, famines, and earthquakes are just the beginning of the events that will lead to the end of the age. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

09.ref: they will deliver you up to tribulation and kill you
09.text: "people will give you over to the authorities who will make you suffer and will kill you."

09.ref: You will be hated by all the nations
09.text: Here "nations" refers to the people of nations. This can be stated in active form. AT: "People from every nation will hate you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "name" refers to the complete person. AT: "because you believe in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

12.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will sin more and more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

12.ref: the love of many will grow cold
12.text: Possible meanings are 1) "many people will no longer love other people" or 2) "many people will no longer love God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

It is not clear whether the "end" means when a person dies, or when the persecution ends, or the end of the age when God shows himself to be king. The main point is that they endure as long as necessary.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will deliver that person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

12.ref: This gospel of the kingdom will be preached
12.text: Here "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. This can be stated in active form. AT: "People will speak this message about God's rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here, "nations" stands for people. AT: "all people in all places" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The end of the world" or "The end of the age"

15.text: "the shameful one who defiles the things of God"

15.ref: which was spoken of by Daniel the prophet
15.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "about which Daniel the prophet wrote" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is not Jesus speaking. Matthew added this to alert the reader that Jesus was using words that they would need to think about and interpret.

15.ref: let him who is on the housetop
15.text: Housetops where Jesus lived were flat, and people could stand on them.

19.text: This is a polite way to say "pregnant women." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism|Euphemism]])

19.ref: that your flight will not occur
19.text: "that you do not have to flee" or "that you do not have to run away"

19.ref: Unless those days are shortened, no flesh would be saved
19.text: This can be stated in positive and active form. AT: "If God does not shorten the time of suffering, everyone will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives|Double Negatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
"people." Here, "flesh" is poetic way of saying all people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche|Synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will shorten the time of suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

23.text: Jesus continues speaking to his disciples.
"do not believe the false things they have said to you"
This is an idiom. AT: "so as to cause people to disobey God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

23.ref: astray, if possible, even the elect
23.text: This can be translated as a separate sentence. AT: "astray. If possible, they will even cause the elect to disobey God"

26.ref: if they say to you, 'Look, he is in the wilderness,'
26.text: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "if someone tells you that the Christ is in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

26.ref: Or, 'See, he is in the inner rooms,'
26.text: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "Or, if someone tells you that the Christ is in the inner room" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"in a secret room" (UDB) or "in secret places"

26.ref: as the lightning shines ... so will be the coming
26.text: This means the Son of Man will come very fast and he will be easy to see. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

26.ref: Wherever a dead animal is, there the vultures will gather
26.text: This is probably a proverb that the people of Jesus' time understood. Possible meanings are 1) when the Son of Man comes, everyone will see him and know that he has come, or 2) wherever spiritually dead people are, false prophets will be there to tell them lies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
birds that eat the bodies of dead or dying creatures

29.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will make the sun dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

29.ref: the powers of the heavens will be shaken
29.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will shake things in the sky and above the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

30.ref: the Son of Man ... He ... his
30.text: Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here "tribes" refers to people. AT: "all the people of the tribes" or "all the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

30.ref: He will send his angels with a great sound of a trumpet
30.text: "When the trumpet sounds, he will send his angels" or "When an angel blows the trumpet, he will send his angels"
These are the people whom the Son of Man has chosen.

30.ref: from the four winds, from one end of the sky to the other
30.text: Both of these mean the same thing. They are idioms that mean "from everywhere." AT: "from all over the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

32.text: Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "the time for me to come is near" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

"close to the gates." Jesus uses the imagery of a king or important official getting close to the gates of a walled city. It is a metaphor meaning the time for Jesus to come is soon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

34.text: "I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

34.ref: this generation will not pass away
34.text: Here "pass away" is a polite way of referring to death. AT: "the people living today will not all die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

34.ref: until all of these things will have happened
34.text: "until God causes all these things to happen"

34.ref: Heaven and the earth will pass away
34.text: "Heaven and the earth will no longer exist"

34.ref: my words will never pass away
34.text: Here "words" refers to what Jesus has said. AT: "what I say will always be true" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

36.text: Here "day" and "hour" refer to the exact time that the Son of Man will return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

37.ref: As the days of Noah were, so will be the coming of the Son of Man
37.text: "At the time when the Son of Man comes, it will be like the time of Noah."
Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

37.ref: the ark, and they knew nothing
37.text: This can be translated as a separate sentence. AT: "the ark. And the people did not realize anything was happening"

37.ref: away—so will be the coming of the Son of Man
37.text: This can be translated as a separate sentence. AT: "away. This is how it will be when the Son of Man comes"

40.text: Jesus begins to tell his disciples to be ready for his return.
This is when the Son of Man comes.

40.ref: one will be taken, and one will be left
40.text: Possible meanings are 1) the Son of Man will take one away to heaven and will leave the other on earth for punishment or 2) the angels will take one away for punishment and leave the other for blessing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Because of what I have told you"

43.ref: that if the master of the house ... broken into
43.text: Jesus uses a parable of a master and servants to illustrate that his disciples should be prepared for his return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
Jesus is saying he will come when people are not expecting him, not that he will come to steal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

43.ref: he would have been on guard
and would not have allowed his house to be broken into
43.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and he would not have allowed anyone to get into his house to steal things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

45.text: Jesus continues his proverb of a master and servants to illustrate that his disciples should be prepared for his return.

45.ref: So who is the faithful and wise servant whom his master ... time?
45.text: Jesus uses this question to make his disciples think. AT: "So who is the faithful and wise servant? He is the one whom his master ... time" or "Be like the faithful and wise servant, whom his master ... time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"give the people in the master's home their food"
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

48.text: Jesus concludes his proverb of a master and servants to illustrate that his disciples should be prepared for his return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]])
Here "heart" refers to the mind. AT: "thinks in his mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "My master is slow to return" or "My master will not return for a long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

48.ref: on a day that the servant does not expect and at an hour that he does not know
48.text: Both of these statements mean the same thing. They emphasize that the master will come when the servant is not expecting him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This is an idiom that means to make the person suffer terribly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This represents extreme sadness and suffering. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:08:11|8:12]].
